Daza's eyebrows rise slightly—the expression of a man presented with an interesting problem rather than an impossible one. He strokes his chin, thinking aloud.


"Crown assessors... crown marshalls..." He nods slowly. "The principles are sound, Your Majesty. God knows Byzantine tax collection is a catastrophe. They collect five thousand florins while the Italians extract twenty thousand from the same harbor. The inefficiency is not merely corruption—though there is plenty of that—it is structural. Fragmented collection, no central accounting, tax farmers skimming half before anything reaches the treasury."


He begins pacing, as he often does when working through administrative puzzles.


"But the implementation..." He turns back to face you. "Forgive me, Your Majesty, but I must speak plainly. Constantinople is not Granada."


Álvaro de Luna shifts in his seat, clearly interested in where this is going.


"In Granada," Daza continues, "we had advantages. Proximity—I can ride from Toledo to Granada in a week if pressed. Language—we imposed Castilian administration on a conquered territory. And legitimacy of conquest—no one questioned our right to reform what we had taken by the sword."


He ticks off the differences on his fingers. "Constantinople is three months away by sea. The Greeks speak Greek, keep records in Greek, think in Greek. And the arrangement—" he gestures to the Chrysobull on the table, "—explicitly preserves the Emperor's dignity. We are partners, not conquerors. If I send Castilian assessors to demand Greek merchants open their books... how does that appear?"


"Like occupation," Álvaro says quietly.


"Precisely." Daza nods. "The March amendment even requires that any Sakellarios we appoint must have a Greek deputy nominated by the Emperor. The intent is clear—this must be their reform as much as ours, or it will breed resentment that poisons the entire arrangement."


He pauses, then his expression shifts—less cautious, more calculating.


"However."


He returns to the table, pulling out a blank sheet and beginning to sketch notes.


"There is another approach. We do not send Castilian assessors to replace Greek officials. We send Castilian advisors to train them. Men who understand our methods—the standardized assessment, the central ledgers, the separation of collection from enforcement. They work alongside Greek officials, not above them."


He looks up. "The Sakellarios—whoever Your Majesty appoints to administer the joint treasury—becomes the key. He implements Castilian methods through Greek hands. The Emperor's dignity is preserved because his officials are doing the work. But the system is ours."

Daza's eyes brighten—this is clearly the part that interests him most.


"That we can reform directly, Your Majesty. The Chrysobull gives the Defensor authority over all revenues flowing to the joint treasury. Create a lex mercatoria court—" he pauses, "—which Your Majesty has already done—that makes Byzantine law predictable and fair."


He spreads his hands. "The Latins who elected Roman citizenship under the Chrysobull of the Choice—they want honest administration. They chose Constantinople over Galata precisely because Your Majesty offered them something the Italians cannot: justice without favoritism. Give them efficient taxation as well, and the revenues will grow of their own accord."


Álvaro leans forward. "How long before we see results?"


Daza considers. "If we appoint a capable Sakellarios and give him two or three good men who understand our methods... a year to establish the new systems. Two years before revenues begin to show meaningful growth. Five years before Constantinople's customs rival Galata's." He shrugs. "Assuming no wars, no plagues, no disasters."


He looks at you directly. "The question, Your Majesty, is who. Who do we send to be Sakellarios? He must understand Castilian administration, but also have the... temperament... to work with Greeks rather than command them. And he must be someone Your Majesty trusts absolutely, because he will be handling enormous sums at an enormous distance."
